title.narrative: Small Grants Facility for civil society

description.narrative:
PADETC uses the small grants facility (SGF) as a vehicle to share its experiences and to strengthen the capacities of emerging Non-Profit Associations (NPAs), while helping coordinate and support the implementation of the CSO statement on aid and development effectiveness.
Specifically, PADETC facilitate both the operation of the Learning for development Association (former LHD) and supportsthe coordination and coaching of the NPAs in their work in the three following areas:
1. Policy advocacy; 2. Institution strengthening; 3. Direct services
The small grants are to help NPAs to operationalise and balance among these three areas of work. For example if there are enough activities in direct services already but not enough on policy advocacy, the small grant will be in favor ofgiving more support for activities related to policy advocacy. On the other hand if many NPAs are giving direct services in disarray, the small grant will be provided to coordinate approaches and to strengthen inter-agency team work in service delivery. For institutional building, the SGF promotes two levels of work. One is to nurture potential youth groups, women groups, and production groups to become organized and officially recognised. The other, is to promote issue-based networking of NPAs working in the areas of natural resources, education, and development of social enterprises.

participating-org.narrative:
PADETC (Participatory Development Training Centre) was officially founded in late 1996. With an initial staff of five Lao development workers (four men and one woman), PADETC#s broad objective was to promote alternative models of development aimed at helping Laos# people to find ways to improve their livelihoods in a just and sustainable way. Prior to its founding its director and his small team of development workers had worked in various aspects of agriculture and integrated rural development in many rural communities in Laos for more than 15 years, with the support mainly from international NGOs and some UN agencies. During the early 1980s the team#s work had focused mainly on improvement of food security in poor rural communities by promoting low-cost appropriate agriculturaltechnologies, such as use of bio-fertilisers and bio-pesticides, and integration of fish-raising in the rice fields, etc. The impetus for working on food security during that time was the need to address the problem of food shortages faced by many rural communities in the aftermath of the 30-year war of independence which ended only in 1975. It was through working on these agriculture-related projects that the team understood that the food security of Lao rural communities could not be solely resolved through improvements in agricultural techniques, but must be systematically tackled at a multi-dimensional level. From the early 1990s onwards PADETC broadened its work to include integrated rural development, with the emphasison strengthening the capacities of rural communities andempower them to improve their livelihoods systematically. The main strategic approaches used included: the promotion of participatory processes for community development, especially the use of participatory processes in problem analysis and planning in collaboration with local authorities and communities; the training of multi-sector rural development teams comprising staff from the agriculture, education, health, and woman#s unions at various levels (village, district, province); the setting up of integrated rural development offices at the provincial and district levels to provide management, extension, and monitoring support; and the production of Lao language manuals and forms for village surveys, planning, budgeting, reporting, and many types of production techniques. With the expansion of its scope of work programmatically and geographically, PADETC has grown from its original staff of five in 1996 to anorganisation with 53 staff (12 women), all of them Lao. PADETC also draws on the support from international expertise in the form of short-term technical experts, advisors and volunteers, etc. through international agencies, such as German International Aid (DED), Singapore International Foundation (SIF), Australia Volunteer Service, etc. PADETC continues to co-operate closely with governmentagencies at all administrative levels and ensures that responsible authorities are regularly briefed on the progress of its projects. PADETC has closeco-operation with a number of NGOs, UN and bilateral agencies. After more than ten years of operation and innovative contribution to local development, PADETC is increasingly given more political and social recognition as a local development agency. Basedon its experience the vision and mission of PADETC is to promote the concept of #liveable# communities which balances economic growth with social and cultural vibrancy, environmental harmony, and spiritual development for all. PADETC has long operatedasalaboratory both for development thinking, and for the applied-use of locally appropriate approaches. This has included not only Learning Centre and network development, but the articulation of a conceptual framework for development. In 2009, PADETCbeganthe process of supporting each Learning Centre and Network to become independent, paving the way for eventual registration as individual NPAs.
In July 2012, the founder and long term Director of PADETC Mr. Sombath has handed over the function toMr.Khamphoui Saythalat. The last year, PADETC has focussed much of its energy and resources and the internal transformation of its organisation as well as the AEPF process. Consequently, most of the activities now take place in and around Vientiane, although contacts with youth groups in other provinces still exist.
Also for the coming programme period the institutional transition process will demand a substantial investment in time and resources from PADETC. In order to support the new director in the processa group of “Friends of PADETC” has been formed with international and national members and that provides coaching and technical advice to PADETC.
PADETC will focus on four fields of action. These are: 1. Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) 2. Enabling Environment Support for Lao CSOs (with a particular focus on Organizational Development and Management, and Small Grant Facility) 3. Policy Advocacy (mainly with reference tothe recommendations made from the Impact Assessment report in March2012) 4. Resource mobilization including the marketing and delivery of services for the general public, NPAs and iNGOs.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
